awd_titl_txt: NSF Engineering Research Center for Ultra-wide-area Resilient Electric Energy Transmission Network
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF ERC for Ultra-wide-area Resilient Electric Energy Transmission Network (CURENT) will develop transforming technologies to allow reliable operation of the electric transmission infrastructure across vast distances and over multiple time scales. Perhaps the most important technical challenge over the next several decades will be how to address energy needs without heavy reliance on fossil fuels. The electric power system transmission infrastructure must play a critical role in any viable solution. Unfortunately, the power grid is aging and already operating outside its design limits. Desired performance in efficiency, reliability, and security cannot be attained when renewable sources such as, wind and solar, reach significant levels that will add complexity and uncertainty to system operation. Allowing greater control of demand with smart metering provides an excellent opportunity. Yet, the core challenge facing operation of an extremely large, complex electric network with tens of thousands of transmission lines, buses and potentially millions of control points, remains unaddressed. Ultra-wide-area coordination for system operation is critically needed to avoid future transmission network instabilities and congestion bottlenecks and to minimize the risk of cascading failures. This ERC will seek the fundamental breakthroughs and investigate the enabling technologies needed to achieve a resilient transmission network on a continental scale, while educating a new generation of electric power and energy systems engineering leaders with a global perspective coming from diverse backgrounds. Specifically, the proposed ERC research will:
--Develop new systems methodologies to take advantage of advancements in wide-area measurement and communication to allow coordinated action on a continental ultra-wide scale. Cost effective, Global Positioning System (GPS) time synchronized, wide-area measurements with milliseconds data rate can transform today's granular Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) system into a high resolution system, enabling dynamic observation and control.
--Flatten the control and information structure so it is less hierarchical and can replace, at all levels of the power grid, traditional inflexible operations strategies. The existing grid controls need to be replaced by a simpler, flatter structure of local control operating with guidance from global situational awareness.
--Draw on high performance computing capability to realize large-scale and faster-than-real-time simulation for predictive control (and fast response) to ensure secure and reliable operation. Real-time calculation of the "dynamic state" of the grid on a continental scale will be feasible.
--Investigate the use of widely allocated high power electronic actuators coupled with transmission level energy storage to stabilize grids during disturbances and moderate supply-demand imbalances resulting in high speed power flow control for full use of assets across the interconnected system.

por.por_cntn:
The Center for Ultra-wide-area Resilient Electric Energy Transmission Networks (CURENT) began in August 2011. The driving force for the research was to develop methods for the electric grid that would allow the grid to accommodate a diverse, high-penetration portfolio of renewable energy sources. That initial motivation continues today. In 2011 when the Center began, renewables provided 12% of the total demand with an installed capacity of 146 GW, including hydropower. In the final year of the Center in 2020, renewables provided 21% of the US electricity. Wind energy generation surpassed hydropower in 2019. Wind generation has grown roughly three-fold and solar generation 50-fold since the Center was first proposed. Solar has grown particularly fast in the last few years as prices of PV panels have plummeted. At the same time, the retirement of coal plants in the U.S. has continued with another 9.2 GW retired in 2020 and about 14.2 GW in 2019; this continues trends over the last several years. Electric energy generated by coal dropped to 24% of the total grid generation in 2020 compared to a historical level of over 59% just a few years ago. 

Battery energy storage has started to rapidly increase with 4 GW of additional capacity expected to be installed in 2021. As a form of mobile storage, electric vehicle (EV) sales have continued to expand with around 1.2 million plug-in vehicles on the road today. Forecasts suggest the number of EVs to reach 25% by 2030. These trends have placed new demands on the existing electric power infrastructure as well as new opportunities for grid support. Clearly research on modernizing the grid, as what is being done in CURENT, remains a critical need.

Since inception, CURENT has been developed transforming technologies to allow reliable operation of the electric transmission infrastructure across vast distances and over multiple time scales with high levels of renewables. Specifically, Center research has developed: 

  • systems methodologies to take advantage of advancements in synchronized wide-area measurement and communication and allow coordinated action on a continental scale;
  • a control and information structure which is less hierarchical and can replace, at all levels of the power grid, traditional inflexible operations strategies. Traditional controls replaced by a simpler, flatter structure of local control operating with guidance from global situational awareness;
  • advanced functionality power electronic actuators to stabilize grids during disturbances and moderate supply-demand imbalances allowing for high speed reconfigurability to realize full use of assets across the interconnected system; and
  • high performance computing capability to enable large-scale and faster-than-real-time simulation for predictive control to ensure secure and reliable operation. 

CURENT research is a systems approach to address the challenges of wide area control of the large and complex power grid. The Center approach has been needed in order to: (1) have a sufficiently large and diverse team of researchers to address multiple technical challenges; (2) interact closely with industry in understanding practical system issues; and (3) create the innovative culture needed to transform a large legacy system. The Center identified the following specific goals for performance indicators for the future power system:

  • allow renewable sources to provide 80% of power or greater, without impacting reliability, 
  • increase load participation for wide-area dynamic control by an order of magnitude, 
  • increase transmission capacity utilization by 30%, 
  • reduce carbon emissions consistent with the Paris agreement on climate change, 
  • achieve nation-wide grid situational awareness at all control centers, 
  • develop resiliency approaches for extreme events, and
  • reduce the rate of major power blackouts by 80%. 

We have identified research milestones needed to reach these goals:

  • a distributed control architecture and design methodology, which allows simple low cost control designs to facilitate renewable integration and demand response with limited communication while supporting system needs;
  • new high resolution measurement technologies for synchronized measurements and other sensing technologies;
  • advanced actuation capabilities in inverter designs to support system functions;
  • new transmission system architectures, such as HVDC overlays and multi-terminal HVDC, that can more fully utilize system capacity;
  • new controls and overall designs that support resiliency in the face of extreme events, such as hurricanes and state sponsored cyberattacks;
  • an information system and data architecture that satisfies latency and situational awareness needs;
  • new data analytic methods to support all aspects of power system decision-making;
  • remedial control actions to prevent cascading outages using wide-area measurements; 
  • use of high performance computing to realize large-scale and faster-than-real-time simulation for predictive control coupled with new visualization tools;
  • measurement based approaches to mitigate cybersecurity threats to grid operation;
  • market structures and incentives to ensure optimal pricing, adequate investment in the transmission network, more rapid adoption of renewable technologies, and an understanding of the social benefits of the transformed infrastructure; and
  • an understanding of the societal and behavioral factors that ease the adoption of grid developments, such as extensive demand response and variability of supply.
